questions.question: The Rhesus blood group antigen complex is located on which chromosome?
Antigens of which of the following blood group systems do not cause alloimmunization in anewborn/fetus?
questions.explanation: The Lewis antigens do not cause alloimmunization or hemolytic disease of the fetus and newborn.Alloimmunization/isoimmunisation is defined as an immune response to foreign antigens afterexposure to genetically different cells or tissues.The Kell blood group system is complex and contains many antigens that are highlyimmunogenic. These antigens are the third most potent, after those of the ABO and Rh bloodgroups, at triggering an immune reaction. Anti-Kell causes severe fetal anemia by suppressingfetal RBC synthesis.MNS and Kidd blood types cause alloimmunization. Hemolytic disease of newborn is mild withKidd whereas MNS causes potentially severe anemia.525

questions.question: A pregnant Rh-negative woman presents for her regular antenatal visit. Her Indirect Coombstest is negative. When would you give her prophylactic Anti-D?
questions.explanation: In a non-immunized Rh-negative primigravida, Anti D is given at 28 weeks of gestation. It is alsogiven within 72 hours of delivery.Routine postpartum administration of anti-D immune globulin to at-risk pregnancies within 72hours of delivery decreases the alloimmunization rate by 90 percent.Additionally, the provision of Anti-D immunoglobulin at 28 weeks of gestation reduces thethird-trimester alloimmunization rate from approximately 2 percent to 0.1 percent.

questions.question: Which of the following events in Rh-negative patients does not require Anti-D prophylaxis?
questions.explanation: Postpartum hemorrhage is not an indication of Anti-D prophylaxis.Anti-D prophylaxis is administered to Rh-negative patients in the following circumstances:•• Pregnancy loss due to:• Ectopic pregnancy• Spontaneous abortion/hydatiform mole• Elective abortion•• Fetal death (any trimester)• Procedures:•• Amniocentesis• Chorionic villus sampling•.•• Fetal blood sampling• External cephalic version• Delivery• Trauma• Placental abruption•Unexplained vaginal bleeding during pregnancy

questions.question: Chorionic villus sampling was performed on a G2P1 Rh-negative woman at 10 weeks ofgestation. What is the dose of Anti-D immunoglobulin that should be administered?
questions.explanation: The dose of Anti-D immunoglobulin to be given in the first trimester is 50 µg.All Rh-negative unsensitized women should receive 50 µg of Rh-immune globulin IM in the firsttrimester in the following conditions:• Within 72 hours of induced or spontaneous abortion•Ectopic/molar pregnancy• Chorionic villus sampling526Women with a pregnancy beyond 12 weeks should receive a full dose of 300 µg. Generally, a 300μg dose will protect a woman from fetal hemorrhage of up to 30 mL of fetal whole blood.The dose in the 3rd trimester and post-delivery is 300 μg or 1500 international units (IU).

questions.question: An Rh-negative G2P1 mother delivered her Rh-positive baby by cesarean section. KleihaeurBetke test, as shown in the image, was done. Which of the following statements is trueregarding the test?

options.A: Fetal erythrocytes are the ghost cells
options.C: The reagent used is citric acid

questions.explanation: The reagent used for the Kleihauer-Betke test is citric acid.Kleihauer-Betke test is the most commonly used quantitative test used to detect fetomaternalhemorrhage i.e., the approximate volume of fetal blood entering the maternal circulation. It isalso known as the acid elution test.The principle behind it is that fetal erythrocytes contain hemoglobin F, which is more resistant toacid elution than hemoglobin A.After exposure to acid, only fetal hemoglobin remains, such that after staining, the fetalerythrocytes appear red and adult cells appear as "ghosts." Fetal cells are counted and expressedas a percentage of adult cells.Flow cytometry is the best test for the quantification of fetomaternal hemorrhage. It is moresensitive and accurate as compared to the Kleihauer-Betke test.Flow cytometry can analyze a larger number of cells and is not influenced by maternal levels offetal hemoglobin and fetal levels of maternal hemoglobin. It utilizes monoclonal antibodies toHbF or to the D antigen followed by quantification by fluorescence.Anti-HbF PE1E4Fetal Erthyrocytes HbF++1E31E21E111E1LeucocytesMaternal erythrocytes HbF+Maternal Erthyrocytes Hbf +1E2Logarithmic FL1OMARROW1 E31E4

questions.question: If the volume of fetomaternal hemorrhage is greater than 30 mL whole blood, the dose ofRh-immunoglobulin calculated is:

options.A: 10 μg for every 0.5 mL of fetal RBCs
options.B: 10 μg for every 5 mL of fetal RBCs
options.C: 0.5 μg for every 1 mL of fetal whole blood
options.D: 5 μg for every 10 mL of fetal whole blood

questions.explanation: If the volume of fetomaternal hemorrhage is greater than 30 mL whole blood, the dose ofRh-immune globulin calculated is 10 µg for every 0.5 mL of fetal RBCs.527The calculation is done as follows:• 300 micrograms of Anti-D can neutralize 15 ml of fetal RBCs or 30ml of fetal whole blood..• 50 micrograms of Anti-D can neutralize 2.5 ml of fetal RBCs.The half-life of anti D is 16-24 days. It is administered intramuscularly either in the deltoid or inthe anterolateral aspect of the thigh.

questions.question: A 25-year-old Rh-negative primigravida presents to the antenatal clinic at 12 weeks ofpregnancy. Her husband is found to be Rh-positive. An Indirect Coombs test is also positive.At what critical titer of the test, would the fetus require monitoring for signs of anemia?
questions.explanation: The critical titer for the indirect Coombs test (ICT) is 1:16Protocol for management Rh isoimmunisation is as follows:Management of Rh-negative pregnancyNoisoimmúnisation-1:19Blood group of husband21:16Monitor twice weeklyDeliver at 97 weeksMonitor fetal anemiawith MCA-POVMOM — 1.5Deliver at 37 weeksDeliverHematocriMOMtransfusionMOM -1.5Fetal blood samplingHematooBased on MGA PAvelinoDeliver at 34k brasaskomMiddle Cerebral Årtery – Peak Systolio VelocityMultiples of MedianCOMARROW

questions.question: In modern obstetrics, which of the following investigations is used for monitoring the fetus ofan Rh-negative sensitized mother?
questions.explanation: MCA Doppler peak systolic velocity (PSV) is used for the monitoring of fetuses in Rh-negativesensitized mothers.The middle cerebral artery is used as other fetal vessels require a larger insonating angle andconfers significant measurement error.MCA PSV is enhanced due to increased cardiac output and decreased viscosity of fetal blood,which permits the reliable, noninvasive detection of fetal anemia in cases of blood-groupalloimmunization.If the MCA PSV exceeds 1.5 MoM (multiples of the median) and the gestational age is less than 34or 35 weeks, fetal blood sampling should be considered. MCA Doppler PSV has replacedamniocentesis as the preferred test for the detection of anemia.528

questions.question: In modified Liley's (Queenan) chart, which zone represents a severely affected fetus?
questions.explanation: A severely affected fetus is represented by zone 3.Liley developed a chart of changing amniotic fluid bilirubin levels (delta OD450) and weeksof gestation. Amnionic fluid bilirubin is measured by a spectrophotometer and is demonstrable asa change in optical density absorbance at 450 nm (AOD450).However, middle cerebral artery peak systolic velocity (MCA PCV) is non-invasive and moreaccurate than optical density at 450 nm, hence Liley's chart is no longer used in practice.Liley's chart has three zones as shown below, delineating the severity of rhesus disease.• Liley's zone I (low zone) - mild disease.• Liley's zone II (mid zone) - fetal anemia.• Liley's zone III (high zone) - severely affected fetus and fetal death is imminent.AOD450 (Amniotic fluid spectrophotometric reading).60.50.40.30.20.10.08.06.04888TLiley's chart16182022224262830Weeks gestationOMARROW

questions.question: You are performing a Doppler assessment of a fetal middle cerebral artery. What is thethreshold value of its peak systolic velocity that would prompt you to consider fetal bloodsampling?
questions.explanation: Threshold (critical value) of middle cerebral artery (MCA) peak systolic velocity is 1.5 multiples ofthe median (MoM).If the MCA peak systolic velocity exceeds 1.5 MOM, further evaluation by fetal blood sampling isnecessary to assess the need for fetal transfusion.The anemic fetus shunts blood preferentially to the brain to maintain adequate oxygenation. Thevelocity increases because of increased cardiac output and decreased blood viscosity.In many centers, serial measurement of the peak systolic velocity of the fetal middle cerebralartery has replaced amniocentesis for the detection of fetal anemia. This method provided 100percent sensitivity.529

questions.question: A 32-year-old G4P3 Rh-negative patient with an antibody titer of 1:32 presents to the clinic at30 weeks. A USG reveals features of fetal edema, ascites, and polyhydramnios. Cordocentesiswas done for fetal blood sampling. At what hematocrit value is intrauterine blood transfusionindicated?
questions.explanation: Intrauterine transfusion is done if fetal haematocrit is <30%.The blood for transfusion is usually O negative and cross-matched with the mother's blood. It ishighly packed to achieve a hematocrit of 75 -80%.Intrauterine transfusions may be done intraperitoneally where blood is absorbed throughdiaphragmatic lymphatics. It may also be done intravascularly through the umbilical vein. Thesegments of the umbilical vein used are the intrahepatic portion or at its insertion into theplacenta.Complications of intrauterine transfusion include:• Fetal demise• Chorioamnionitis• Placental abruption•Pre-term labor• Bradycardia/tachyarrhythmia• Umbilical cord hematoma

questions.question: A patient presented for an antenatal checkup at 25 weeks of gestation. She had bilateralpitting pedal edema and a history of mild headaches. While updating her antenatal card, aweight gain of 13 kgs in the past 2 weeks was noted. USG revealed gross fetal hydrops and ahyperechoic placenta. Which of the following is not true about the patient's condition?

options.A: It is also known as Ballantyne syndrome
options.B: Hydrops could be due to rhesus isoimmunization
options.C: It is associated with elevated liver enzymes
options.D: It is a not a form of pre-eclampsia523

questions.explanation: The clinical scenario is suggestive of maternal mirror syndrome/Ballantyne syndrome. It may beconsidered a form of severe pre-eclampsia.Maternal mirror syndrome is the association between fetal hydrops and the development ofmaternal edema. The syndrome is named as such because the mother mirrors the fetus. It ischaracterized by triple edema i.e., the fetus, mother, and placenta become edematous.The pathogenesis of mirror syndrome, although not well established, mimics trophoblasticdamage and maternal vascular endothelial dysfunction, as is also seen in pre-eclampsia. Hence,these two conditions may have a similar clinical presentation, with common features such as:• Edema• Hypertension• Proteinuria• Liver enzyme elevation• Headache and visual disturbances.However, in contrast to preeclampsia, the following features are noted in maternal mirrorsyndrome:• Low maternal hematocrit i.e., hemodilution rather than hemoconcentration•Polyhydramnios rather than oligohydramnios• The fetus always shows signs of hydrops.530The etiology of fetal hydrops is not related to the development of mirror syndrome. Hydrops couldbe due to rhesus isoimmunization, twin-twin transfusion syndrome, congenital infections, fetalcystic hygroma, Ebstein anomaly, sacrococcygeal teratoma, vein of Galen aneurysms, etc.In most cases with mirror syndrome, prompt delivery is indicated, because women with severefeatures of preeclampsia can deteriorate rapidly. In few cases, identification and treatment of thecause of fetal hydrops resulted in the resolution of symptoms for both the mother and baby for theremainder of the pregnancy.

questions.question: An ultrasound was done on a pregnant Rh-negative patient to screen for hydrops fetalis.What is the earliest sign that may be seen on USG?
questions.explanation: The earliest sign of hydrops fetalis on a USG is scalp edema. Subcutaneous scalp edema is alsoknown as the Halo sign.Other USG signs include:• Ascites•Pleural effusion•Pericardial effusion•Typical position termed as Buddha's positionThe image below shows skin thickening at the level of the fetal skull, on ultrasonography:HC4.0MHOBNTHI Gen78dB SGain= 0Store in p

questions.question: An Rh-negative patient who did not have access to antenatal care delivered a stillborn fetus asshown in the image. Which of the following is not associated with the fetal condition?
questions.explanation: The pale, oedematous fetus in the image is suggestive of fetal hydrops. Fetal hydrops is associatedwith polyhydramnios, not oligohydramnios.It often occurs as an effect of iso-immunization in an Rh-negative pregnancy. Other complicationsthat may occur are fetal anemia and hyperbilirubinemia.531Fetal anemia occurs in the initial stage of iso-immunization. It is associated with polyhydramniosand increased placental thickening (hyper-placentosis). An increase in the right atrium size of thefetus is seen.Fetal hydrops is usually accompanied by severe anemia. It results in stillbirth or fetal demise soonafter birth. It is also associated with:••••Congestive cardiac failure• AscitesPleural effusionPericardial effusion• Hepatosplenomegaly.Fetal anemia due tohemolysisHydrops fetalisExtramedullaryhematopoiesisInccreasedinterstitial fluidHepatic dysfunctionImpaired proteinsynthesisDecreased plasmaoncotic pressure532
